author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Why Did Modi Call India’s Muslims ‘Infiltrators’? Because He Could.
description: The brazenness of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s vilification of India’s largest minority group made clear he sees few checks at home or abroad on his power.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, his power at home secured and his Hindu-first vision deeply entrenched, has set his sights in recent years on a role as a global statesman, riding India’s economic and diplomatic rise. In doing so, he has distanced himself from his party’s staple work of polarizing India’s diverse population along religious lines for its own electoral gain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Shorto
title: New York Is Turning 400. We Should Celebrate. But How?
description: We need history to support our foundations. But it can only do that with integrity if it exposes the failings.
content: This spring is the 400th anniversary of the founding of New York — or, to be precise, of the Dutch colony that became New York once the English took it over. It’s a noteworthy milestone. That settlement gave rise to a city unencumbered by old ways and powered by pluralism and capitalism: the first modern city, you might say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Juliet Macur
title: Justice Dept. Reaches $138.7 Million Settlement Over F.B.I.’s Failures in Nassar Case
description: The settlement likely signifies the end of a yearslong effort by U.S. Olympic gymnasts to seek justice for early failures by the F.B.I. to investigate Lawrence G. Nassar, the team’s doctor.
content: The Justice Department said on Tuesday it would pay $138.7 million to resolve claims by young women and girls, including many top female gymnasts, of sexual abuse by the former U.S.A. Gymnastics doctor Lawrence G. Nassar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jed Handelsman Shugerman
title: I Thought the Bragg Case Against Trump Was a Legal Embarrassment. Now I Think It’s a Historic Mistake.
description: It’s not the crime; it’s the cover-up. But it’s still a highly flawed case.
content: About a year ago, when Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, indicted former President Donald Trump, I was critical of the case and called it an embarrassment. I thought an array of legal problems would and should lead to long delays in federal courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Alan Feuer
title: New York Court System to Publish Daily Transcripts of Trump’s Trial
description: A government website will also contain relevant documents for the landmark trial, which is not televised.
content: If you want to follow Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in detail but can’t make it to the Lower Manhattan courthouse in person, you can still read every word of the proceedings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: In San Francisco, a Home Renovation Can Become a Battle Royale
description: Neighbors have multiple opportunities to raise objections, and some disputes can only be resolved by the city’s top governing body.
content: San Francisco’s top governing body spent time on Tuesday discussing what most residents surely would not consider a major priority for the city: whether Julie Park and Tom McDonald can raise the roof of their $2.1 million Victorian home by 7 feet and 3 inches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: To Be (Visibly) Jewish in the Ivy League
description: Behavior that would be scandalous if aimed at other minorities is treated as understandable or even commendable when directed at Jews.
content: Netanel Crispe, from Danby, Vt., is a 21-year-old junior studying American history at Yale. He is also, to his knowledge, the university’s only Hasidic undergraduate. When he chose Yale, he told me this week, he was “looking for an institution that asserted its position in terms of maintaining and protecting free expression while not backing down on its principal values.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Voices Below Sopranos
description: Judy Bowers makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: ‘It Is Desolate’: China’s Glut of Unused Car Factories
description: Manufacturers like BYD, Tesla and Li Auto are cutting prices to move their electric cars. For gasoline-powered vehicles, the surplus of factories is even worse.
content: On the outskirts of Chongqing, western China’s largest city, sits a huge symbol of the country’s glut of car factories. It’s a complex of gray buildings, nearly a square mile in size. The thousands of employees who used to work there have moved on. Its crimson loading docks are closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Who Can Be Trusted for Retirement Advice? New Rules Strengthen Protections.
description: More investment professionals will be required to act in their customers’ best interest when providing advice about their retirement money.
content: When you walk into a financial adviser’s office, you expect them to put your best interests above all else — in the same way a doctor would, rather than, say, a car salesman. But many people don’t realize that the rules financial professionals must follow vary, depending on where they work and what products they’re selling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes
title: New Yorkers vs. Cockroaches: ‘It’s Them or Me.’
description: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.
content: It was the early 1970s, and we had set up our little company, Cyclops Films, at 1600 Broadway. We were equipped with a newly purchased Éclair NPR, a Nagra recorder and our infatuation with cinéma vérité.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Planned Parenthood Plans $10 Million Boost for Democrats in North Carolina
description: The party is banking on abortion access as an issue to animate the state’s competitive race for governor and, they hope, galvanize voters for President Biden.
content: Aiming to bring the national fight over abortion access to a key battleground state, a political arm of Planned Parenthood will spend $10 million on organizing efforts in North Carolina this year, its largest-ever investment in a single state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Senate Votes on Ukraine Aid
description: Also, a former tabloid publisher testifies against Donald Trump.
content: The Senate is on track to pass the $95 billion package of foreign aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. A final vote is expected in the next few hours, and President Biden plans to sign it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Finale Recap: Mask Off
description: Lord Toranaga’s true plan is finally revealed.
content: Take a look at any of FX’s promotional material for “Shogun,” and one image will stare back: Lord Toranaga (Hiroyuki Sanada), in full samurai armor, his sword drawn as he charges into battle on a white horse. Tattered red banners and a cavalry provide the backdrop. It doesn’t require close reading to determine that he has cried havoc and let slip the dogs of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Universities Struggle as Pro-Palestinian Demonstrations Grow
description: Dozens were arrested Monday at N.Y.U. and Yale, but officials there and at campuses across the country are running out of options to corral protests that are expected to last the rest of the school year.
content: At New York University, the police swept in to arrest protesting students on Monday night, ending a standoff with the school’s administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan McCarthy
title: Your most pressing climate questions
description: Introducing Ask NYT Climate, where we’ll explore how climate intersects with your everyday life.
content: Are traffic circles better for the environment than four-way stops? Will the oceans be too hot for fish to survive? Is green hydrogen a thing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Brockes
title: Her Father Was a Hippie Dropout. He Was Also an Aristocrat (Sort Of).
description: In “The Whole Staggering Mystery,” Sylvia Brownrigg explores her mysterious parent’s past, and finds more than she bargained for.
content: In the opening pages of “The Whole Staggering Mystery,” Sylvia Brownrigg makes a case for memoir in the age of the genome. Now that mysteries of lineage can be solved via quick DNA test, “family secrets,” she writes, “aren’t what they used to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: In Ukraine, New American Technology Won the Day. Until It Was Overwhelmed.
description: Project Maven was meant to revolutionize modern warfare. But the conflict in Ukraine has underscored how difficult it is to get 21st-century data into 19th-century trenches.
content: The idea triggered a full-scale revolt on the Google campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,039
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 8 Songs From the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s Class of 2024
description: Listen to soon-to-be inductees Cher, Foreigner, A Tribe Called Quest and more.
content: On Sunday night, the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame announced its 2024 inductees. And while I find this year’s class a tad less exciting than last year’s, there are still quite a few names I was pleased to see: A Tribe Called Quest, Kool & the Gang, Ozzy Osbourne, Mary J. Blige and the artist who would have been at the top of my ballot, if I were a Rock Hall voter: Cher.*
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Trump’s ‘eyes and ears’ for scandal
description: A tabloid publisher testified how he helped Trump’s 2016 campaign.
content: If last week’s process of selecting jurors was a kind of prologue to the criminal trial of Donald Trump, today marked the robust beginning of the first act, complete with introduction of the plot and foreshadowing of future drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: F.T.C. Issues Ban on Worker Noncompete Clauses
description: The rule would prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals, a change that could increase competition and boost wages.
content: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday said employers could no longer, in most cases, stop their employees from going to work for rival companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Yan Zhuang
title: Strong Aftershocks From Deadly Quake Rattle Taiwan
description: No injuries or deaths were immediately reported, but four buildings partially collapsed in the tremors, which followed a powerful April 3 quake that killed 17 people.
content: Taiwan was shaken by a series of earthquakes on Monday and early Tuesday, the strongest with a magnitude of 6.3, partially toppling four buildings and keeping frightened residents up overnight. The tremors were aftershocks from the magnitude 7.4 quake that killed 17 people three weeks ago, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla’s Profit Fell 55%, Adding to Concerns About Its Strategy
description: The first-quarter results are likely to fuel worries that competitors will continue grabbing a bigger slice of a market dealing with slowing electric car sales.
content: Tesla reported on Tuesday that it made significantly less money in the first three months of the year because of its tepid car sales, reinforcing concern among investors that the company led by Elon Musk is losing ground in the market for electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Wasik and Monica Murphy
title: How Do We Know What Animals Are Really Feeling?
description: Animal-welfare science tries to get inside the minds of a huge range of species — in order to help improve their lives.
content: What makes a desert tortoise happy? Before you answer, we should be more specific: We’re talking about a Sonoran desert tortoise, one of a few species of drab, stocky tortoises native to North America’s most arid landscapes. Adapted to the rocky crevices that striate the hills from western Arizona to northern Mexico, this long-lived reptile impassively plods its range, browsing wildflowers, scrub grasses and cactus paddles during the hours when it’s not sheltering from the brutal heat or bitter cold. Sonoran desert tortoises evolved to thrive in an environment so different from what humans find comfortable that we can rarely hope to encounter one during our necessarily short forays — under brimmed hats and layers of sunblock, carrying liters of water and guided by GPS — into their native habitat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: The Sinking Arizona Town Where Water and Politics Collide
description: Democrats see an opening to win back rural Trump voters fed up with their groundwater being pumped by huge farms.
content: In Arizona’s deeply conservative La Paz County, the most urgent issue facing many voters is not inflation or illegal immigration. It is the water being pumped from under their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Plans to Expand ‘Humanitarian Zone’ if It Invades Rafah
description: An oceanside area currently crowded with displaced Gazans is among the sites being eyed for a larger safe zone for evacuees, a military official said.
content: If Israel were to begin an invasion in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, where a million displaced Palestinians are sheltering, an Israeli-designated “humanitarian zone” along the coast would be expanded to take in more civilians, an Israeli military official said Monday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Here’s What’s in the Foreign Aid Package That Is About to Become Law
description: Assistance for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan is paired with legislation to impose fresh rounds of sanctions on Iran and Russia and a measure that could lead to a ban on TikTok in the United States.
content: The Senate on Tuesday approved a $95.3 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan that had been stalled in Congress for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Abortion Data Wars: States and Cities Debate How Much Information to Collect
description: Some states with Republican-controlled legislatures want more data, while some controlled by Democrats want less, fearing it could be used to target patients or providers.
content: In the fierce debate over abortion in the United States, the subject of data collection might seem wonky and tangential. But the information that state and city governments collect about abortion patients is becoming another flashpoint in the country’s bitter divide over the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: Kamasi Washington Wants to Remain Unstoppable
description: Nine years after the release of the album that changed his life, the saxophonist is bringing new collaborators and new parts of himself into his work.
content: Before Kamasi Washington unveiled his breakthrough opus, he admits, he second-guessed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Hiba Yazbek and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Calls for Inquiry Into Mass Graves at 2 Gaza Hospitals
description: Palestinian officials said scores of bodies had been found, some shot in the head, at one hospital after Israeli forces withdrew. Israel said it had dug up and reburied some bodies in a search for hostages.
content: The United Nations’ human rights office on Tuesday called for an independent investigation into two mass graves found after Israeli forces withdrew from hospitals in Gaza, including one discovered days ago over which Israeli and Palestinian authorities offered differing accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell on How ‘Anyone but You’ Beat the Rom-Com Odds
description: Here are their takeaways after the film, debuting on Netflix, went from box office miss to runaway hit.
content: As Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell promoted their romantic comedy, “Anyone but You,” last year, life appeared to be imitating art: The co-stars posed cheek to cheek while sightseeing in Australia. Powell dipped a gleeful Sweeney in his arms. Sweeney cast longing gazes up at Powell on red carpets. The pair flirted and giggled in interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Are You Too Critical of Yourself?
description: Do you feel pressure to be the best or to never make mistakes?
content: Think of a time when something didn’t go as well as you had hoped — a time, for example, when you made a mistake, did poorly on a test or were cut from a team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Will Speak at Morehouse and West Point Graduations
description: President Biden will deliver the commencement addresses in May as U.S. support for Israel fuels protests on other campuses.
content: President Biden will deliver commencement addresses next month at Morehouse College in Georgia and the U.S. Military Academy at West Point at a time when anger over U.S. foreign policy has led to an eruption of student protests at several campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Donors Stay Largely Silent Amid New Wave of Campus Protests
description: Robert Kraft, an alumnus of Columbia, suggested he would withhold donations to the school. Other alumni are keeping quiet.
content: Top American colleges are in turmoil, with dozens of pro-Palestinian student protesters having been arrested at N.Y.U. and Yale amid new worries about antisemitism on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: Trump’s Trial Features Fierce Debate Over What He Can Say: 5 Takeaways
description: Donald J. Trump’s lawyer was harshly questioned as he tried to avoid a contempt citation. And a publisher testified about how he put The National Enquirer to work for Mr. Trump’s campaign.
content: Tuesday’s session of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial began with a heated clash between Justice Juan M. Merchan and Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer over a gag order. It ended with an insider’s look into a tabloid newspaper practice known as “catch and kill.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum
title: Could Trump Go to Prison? If He Does, the Secret Service Goes, Too
description: Officials have had preliminary discussions about how to protect the former president in the unlikely event that he is jailed for contempt during the trial.
content: The U.S. Secret Service is in the business of protecting the president, whether he’s inside the Oval Office or visiting a foreign war zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Will Reid, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mooj Zadie, Lexie Diao, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: A Salacious Conspiracy or Just 34 Pieces of Paper?
description: Inside the criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The prosecution and the defense both opened their cases on Monday in the first criminal trial of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Ellmann
title: Danielle Dutton’s Surreal Take on Human Existence
description: “Prairie, Dresses, Art, Other,” the author’s new collection, ranges from a playful one-act drama set in a lake to short fiction rife with apocalyptic anxiety.
content: Aspiring writers now get M.F.A.s in creative writing, instead of studying literature, and novelists end up teaching these people rather than attending to their own work. Almost any other day job would be preferable, since editing students’ literary efforts not only pays badly, it sucks exactly the same imaginative energy out of you that you need to write your own stuff. Once neutralized in this way, some writer-teachers compound the misstep by mining academe for material. Big mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: He’s Music’s Mr. Adjacent, Connecting Minimalism to Disco
description: Peter Gordon, who studied with Terry Riley, has always made music that is surprising but accessible. Now he’s starting his own record label.
content: For 45 years, Peter Gordon has held onto a reel-to-reel tape of a show he performed in 1979 at the Mudd Club in New York City with a trio called the Blue Horn File. Gordon, the violinist Laurie Anderson and the percussionist David Van Tieghem — a group of new music all-stars — did a short set with the playful and unshackled feel of cartoon music. It was one of only three shows the Blue Horn File played.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Alan Blinder, Kate Christobek, Julian E. Barnes, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Campus Antiwar Protests Grow, and Trump Fights Attempts to Silence Him
description: Plus, “Blair Witch” actors push for royalties.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Are Younger Adults Developing This Common Heart Condition?
description: New research suggests that A-fib may be more prevalent, and more dangerous, in people under 65 than previously thought.
content: Atrial fibrillation, a common cardiac condition that raises the risk of stroke, is increasingly affecting the health of people under the age of 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Venutolo-Mantovani
title: Why You Should Add Some Sprints Into Your Workout
description: Running all out, at least for short distances, can be a great way to level up your workout routine.
content: When was the last time you sprinted?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: These Voters Haven’t Missed an Election in at Least 50 Years
description: A relatively small share of voters participate in off-year elections, and even fewer make a habit of it. Counties in Pennsylvania honor voters who show up every time.
content: In 1963, Leola Hubbard voted for the first time. She was 21, and she sent her absentee ballot home from college in Georgia to be counted in Montgomery County, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Ben Casselman
title: ‘Pay Later’ Lenders Have an Issue With Credit Bureaus
description: Firms like Experian and TransUnion say it is time for “buy now, pay later” loans to appear on consumer credit reports. The lenders aren’t ready to sign on.
content: Shoppers in recent years have embraced “buy now, pay later” loans as an easy, interest-free way to purchase everything from sweaters to concert tickets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Approves Aid for Ukraine and Israel, Sending It to Biden’s Desk
description: The overwhelming bipartisan vote for the long-stalled $95.3 billion aid package capped a tortured journey for the legislation on Capitol Hill. President Biden is expected to quickly sign it.
content: The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday night to give final approval to a $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, sending it to President Biden and ending months of uncertainty about whether the United States would continue to back Kyiv in its fight against Russian aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 317
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Reports Big Jump in Profit on Gasoline Car Sales
description: General Motors has struggled with electric vehicles and in foreign markets but it is selling lots of combustion engine cars and trucks in North America.
content: General Motors on Tuesday reported a big jump in profits for the first three months of the year, based on the strength of its gasoline vehicle business, and raised its outlook for the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Asia Heat Wave Bakes Millions, Disrupting Work and Agriculture
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 23, 2024.
content: “I haven’t experienced heat like this before. Every year gets hotter, but this year is extreme.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: It’s All Right to Groove to Huey in ‘The Heart of Rock and Roll’
description: The new musical doesn’t take itself too seriously and has many winning moments — almost enough to eclipse the weaknesses of its story.
content: It’s 2024, and Huey Lewis is having a moment. Just let that sink in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: What to Watch: ‘Baby Reindeer,’ an Astonishing Stalker Drama
description: The Netflix series is based on the real-life experience of its creator, Richard Gadd, who also stars in the show.
content: Richard Gadd created and stars in the mesmerizing, complex drama “Baby Reindeer” (on Netflix), which is based on his experience of being stalked. Here he plays Donny Dunn, an aspiring comedian and miserable bartender, living with his ex-girlfriend’s mother and stewing in regret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Malaysian Navy Helicopters Collide Midair, Killing All 10 People Aboard
description: The two helicopters were rehearsing for a parade to celebrate the navy’s 90th anniversary.
content: Two Malaysian Navy helicopters collided midair during a training session in the northwestern state of Perak on Tuesday, killing all 10 people on board, at least the second accident involving government aircraft in the Southeast Asian country in as many months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Judge Questions Credibility of Trump’s Lawyer as Witness Details Coverup Allegations
description: Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan is off to an ominous start for the former president, and it might not get any easier in the days ahead.
content: The judge questioned his defense lawyer’s credibility. The prosecution accused him of orchestrating a criminal conspiracy to influence the 2016 presidential election. And his former friend corroborated that accusation, delivering hours of gripping testimony about their secret plot to protect his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: How G.M. Tricked Millions of Drivers Into Being Spied On (Including Me)
description: This privacy reporter and her husband bought a Chevrolet Bolt in December. Two risk-profiling companies had been getting detailed data about their driving ever since.
content: Automakers have been selling data about the driving behavior of millions of people to the insurance industry. In the case of General Motors, affected drivers weren’t informed, and the tracking led insurance companies to charge some of them more for premiums. I’m the reporter who broke the story. I recently discovered that I’m among the drivers who was spied on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario, Lindsay Zoladz and Caryn Ganz
title: ‘Tortured Poets’ Has Shifted the Taylor Swift Debate. Let’s Discuss.
description: The superstar’s 11th album is a 31-song excavation of her recent relationships that is not universally loved. Our pop team dissects its sound, themes and reception.
content: BEN SISARIO Hey, have you guys seen my antique typewriter? I think I left it at someone’s apartment. I swear, I’m so absent-minded …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Donald Trump on Trial
description: Highlights from the first big day of the former president’s New York criminal case.
content: A criminal trial is often a contest between competing stories. In the trial of Donald Trump that’s just begun, prosecutors used their opening statement yesterday to tell a story about a man they say lied — and broke the law — to get elected president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Germany Arrests Aide to E.U. Lawmaker on Suspicion of Spying for China
description: The move came just hours after the authorities detained three other people suspected of passing secrets to Beijing.
content: An aide to a German far-right European Parliament lawmaker has been arrested on suspicion of spying for China, Germany’s federal prosecutor’s office said Tuesday, the latest in a series of cases that have intensified concerns about foreign interference in European Union politics weeks before bloc-wide elections.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Did the Israel-Hamas War Influence Your Seder Rituals? Tell Us.
description: We want to know if the war changed the rituals or the tenor of your Seder.
content: For an article later today, The New York Times is hoping to learn more about how the Israel-Hamas war may have affected Seders last night, or preparations for Seders tonight or later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair
title: Trapped and Starving, 2 Families in Gaza Try to Keep Their Children Alive
description: The United Nations says famine is likely to set in by May. For those living under Israel’s attacks and a crippling blockade, every day is a race against time.
content: Born in wartime, the baby had not eaten in more than a day, his father said — no formula, no nothing. His parents had already spent the last of their money on food, sold his mother’s gold jewelry to buy milk and begged water from other evacuees to mix the powdered formula. Now even that was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Problem Was He Smelled Really Good’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My high school friends restart a group text. Basic holiday wishes turn to cheering on professional accomplishments and then to art, music and book recommendations. We send memes, pictures, Spotify links. Most of us have not seen one another in nearly two decades, yet we remember the smell of each other’s childhood homes, how NPR was always playing. There is a sturdiness here, not just in our friendships enduring, but in the reminder that we existed before all this — the babies, the career ambitions, the illnesses. And that, so far, we’ve survived it all. — Kathleen Donahoe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: Costuming a Small Army of Virgins for the Met Opera’s ‘El Niño’
description: The challenge for Montana Levi Blanco, the Tony-winning costume designer for John Adams’s oratorio, was how to keep straight so many Marys.
content: In the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “El Niño,” which reimagines the story of Jesus’ birth and early childhood, there are singing and dancing Virgin Marys, Marys of the land and sea; there’s an Indigenous Mary, a Tropical Mary, a Golden Mary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: This Conversation Made Me a Sharper Editor
description: The venerated editor Adam Moss walks through how to make good work great.
content: In our recent series on artificial intelligence, I kept returning to a thought: This technology might be able to churn out content faster than we can, but we still need a human mind to sift through the dross and figure out what’s good. In other words, A.I. is going to turn more of us into editors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Student Editorial Boards Rebuke College Officials for Protest Decisions
description: Around the nation, editorial boards at college newspapers have defended free speech and pro-Palestinian protesters in recent weeks.
content: As protests over the Israel-Hamas war have erupted at U.S. universities in recent months, student journalists have been reporting daily on campus debates over free speech, university investments and America’s involvement in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Joe Rennison
title: Trump Is Owed an Extra $1 Billion Stake in Truth Social
description: The former president is in line for a windfall after the stock price of Trump Media hit performance targets in its first few weeks of trading, raising the value of his already sizable stake.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s already sizable stake in his social media company is set to jump by more than $1 billion, as he’s rewarded with additional shares in the parent of Truth Social — the result of its stock price staying high in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Very Famous Model Stars in a Very Pixelated Book of Wigs
description: With the model Kaia Gerber, the hairstylist Guido Palau created a “low-fi” project about the transformative power of hair.
content: Guido Palau was sitting in an airport lounge in Miami, on his way to New York. Kaia Gerber was sitting in a car in Los Angeles, on her way to the airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: At Least 5 Die Trying to Cross English Channel, Including a Young Girl
description: British and French authorities have struggled to find ways to deter people from making the perilous journey.
content: At least five people died at sea off the coast of northern France on Tuesday during an attempt to cross the English Channel, as governments on both sides of the waterway struggle to deter migrants from making the dangerous voyage to Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: 20 Years Later, a Jury Weighs Claims of Abuse at Abu Ghraib
description: Three men who were detained at the notorious prison in Iraq are suing a defense contractor, saying its interrogators told U.S. soldiers to “soften up” prisoners.
content: The journalist said he was left naked overnight in a cold prison cell with a bag over his head, chained by his wrists to a pipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: One Walk-in Shower Is as Good as Any Other, Right? Wrong.
description: Here’s how to make your morning shower more luxurious.
content: A utilitarian walk-in shower works just as well as something nicer, so why spend the time and effort — and the money — to upgrade it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Celebrity Bag Designer Sentenced to Jail for Smuggling Exotic Skins
description: Nancy Gonzalez, whose clients included Britney Spears and Sofia Vergara, smuggled purses from her native Colombia to the United States using couriers. She will serve 18 months.
content: The handbag designer Nancy Gonzalez built a cult following among celebrities and the South American superrich thanks to her use of brilliantly dyed precious skins. Once one of the largest purveyors of crocodile skin accessories in the world, her namesake brand sold totes and clutches in lime green alligator and lavender python skin for thousands of dollars, often through big-name retailers like Saks and Bergdorf Goodman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: National Enquirer’s Help for Trump Broke Norms Even in the Tabloid World
description: The tabloid’s parent company was fined for breaking federal election laws after spending money to buy and bury stories that could have harmed Donald J. Trump’s campaign.
content: The National Enquirer was more than a friendly media outlet for Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign in 2016. It was a powerful, national political weapon that was thrust into the service of a single candidate, in violation of campaign finance law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Erizanu
title: My Country Knows What Happens When You Do a Deal With Russia
description: Moldova is a cautionary tale for Ukraine.
content: More and more people, including Pope Francis, are asking Ukraine to drop its defense and sit at the negotiation table with Russia. Citing the stalemate on the battlefield and Russia’s superior resources, they urge Ukraine’s leadership to consider a deal. What exactly that would involve is largely left unsaid. But it would clearly involve freezing the conflict, resigning Ukraine’s occupied territory to Russia in exchange for an end to the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Ukraine Aid in the Light of History
description: Lessons of Lend-Lease for the current crisis.
content: On Saturday the House of Representatives finally overcame MAGA opposition and approved a new aid package for Ukraine. The Biden administration presumably had matériel ready to ship, just waiting for congressional authorization, so the effects of this legislative breakthrough will be quick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Small-Business Tyrant Has a Favorite Political Party
description: It has never been more obvious that the Republican Party is the party of the boss.
content: Despite the blue-collar affectations of some of its most visible leaders or the populist rhetoric of its most vocal cheerleaders, it has never been more obvious that the Republican Party is the party of the boss, and in particular the party of the small-business tyrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ray Mark Rinaldi and Amanda Villarosa
title: You Can Sit There. Really.
description: At the Denver Art Museum, a furniture exhibition lets visitors experience museum fare as more than just pretty objects.
content: The first thing that greets visitors at the Denver Art Museum’s new exhibition of contemporary furniture is a rather large sign announcing the show’s name. “Have a Seat: Mexican Chair Design Today,” it reads in uppercase letters rendered in an eye-popping, pink font.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Sharon Otterman
title: Inside the Week That Shook Columbia University
description: In a Washington war room, Columbia’s president, Nemat Shafik, decided to call police officers to arrest protesting students. The backlash now threatens her leadership.
content: Just after 2 p.m. last Wednesday, Nemat Shafik, the president of Columbia University, stepped out of an office building on Capitol Hill and into an idling black SUV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman, Eliza Fawcett and Liset Cruz
title: A Night Different From Others as Campus Protests Break for Seder
description: Pro-Palestinian protesters, many of whom are Jewish, prepared Seder dinners at college protest encampments, even as other Jewish students sought community in more traditional settings.
content: On the first night of Passover, the singsong of the Four Questions echoed from Jewish homes and gatherings around the world, including from unlikely, contested spaces: the center of pro-Palestinian protests at Columbia and other universities where demonstrations are taking place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Judge Approves $418 Million Settlement That Will Change Real Estate Commissions
description: Home sellers will no longer be required to offer commission to a buyer’s agent when they sell their property, under an agreement with the National Association of Realtors.
content: A settlement that will rewrite the way many real estate agents are paid in the United States has received preliminary approval from a federal judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: To Justify His Immunity Defense, Trump Flips the Prosecution Script
description: The former president’s claim ahead of a pivotal Supreme Court hearing that he was protecting the election system rather than subverting it is part of a pattern of shaping his own reality.
content: When the Supreme Court considers Donald J. Trump’s sweeping claims of executive immunity on Thursday, it will break new legal ground, mulling for the first time the question of whether a former president can avoid being prosecuted for things he did in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: Yellowstone’s Wolves: A Debate Over Their Role in the Park’s Ecosystem
description: New research questions the long-held theory that reintroduction of such a predator caused a trophic cascade, spawning renewal of vegetation and spurring biodiversity.
content: In 1995, 14 wolves were delivered by truck and sled to the heart of Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming, where the animal had long been absent. Others followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Beyoncé Showed Her Hair Being Washed. Here’s Why It Matters.
description: In a video on Instagram, the singer provided fans a rare glimpse of her routine.
content: First, she gave us Disco Beyoncé. Then she gave us Cowboy Beyoncé. And now? Get-Ready-With-Me Beyoncé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Schremp Hahn
title: A St. Louis Museum Revisits a Famous but Complex World’s Fair
description: A new exhibit at the Missouri History Museum examines “the triumphant side and the tragic side” of the 1904 spectacle to present a fuller story.
content: In the final scene of the 1944 musical film “Meet Me in St. Louis,” the Smith family, dressed in fancy attire, wanders the grounds of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, better known as the 1904 World’s Fair. Daylight fades, the electric lights flash on and the group stops in its tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: blithely
description: This word has appeared in 72 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word blithely has appeared in 72 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 8 in “Ariana Grande Spins Heartbreak Into Gold on ‘Eternal Sunshine’” by Lindsay Zoladz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carson Griffith
title: Cait Bailey Can’t Avoid the Spotlight
description: The publicist is by the side of famous people like Zayn Malik, Alex Cooper and Alix Earle. She’s dating a famous chef. But she’d prefer to keep a low profile.
content: “Not tonight,” Cait Bailey told a photographer trying to take her picture inside an area cordoned off for special guests at a Louis Vuitton party at the Miami Beach Convention Center. “Not this time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: New Study Bolsters Idea of Athletic Differences Between Men and Trans Women
description: Research financed by the International Olympic Committee introduced new data to the unsettled and fractious debate about bans on transgender athletes.
content: A new study financed by the International Olympic Committee found that transgender female athletes showed greater handgrip strength — an indicator of overall muscle strength — but lower jumping ability, lung function and relative cardiovascular fitness compared with women whose gender was assigned female at birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: How ‘The Squad’ and Like-Minded Progressives Have Changed Their Party
description: The left’s position on Israel has now become the Democratic Party’s, hinting at greater influence to come.
content: When the far-left politicians Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ayanna Pressley were first elected to Congress roughly half a decade ago, many moderate Democrats saw their unapologetically progressive vision for America as an albatross around the neck of the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Best Fish Is Also the Most Local. Why Is It So Hard to Find?
description: Seafood caught in nearby waters has long been left out of the farm-to-table movement. But these people have set out to get it into stores and restaurants.
content: On a cold, windy February morning on Shinnecock Bay, on the South Fork of Long Island, N.Y., Ricky Sea Smoke fished for clams from the back of his 24-foot boat. The fisherman, whose real name is Rick Stevens, expertly sorted through haul after haul as they were dumped onto the sorting rack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: When Edgar Allan Poe Lived, and Loved, in the Bronx
description: The manuscript of Poe’s poem “For Annie,” written while he was living in a Bronx cottage after his wife’s death, is up for auction.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the manuscript of “For Annie,” a poem that Edgar Allan Poe wrote when he lived in a cottage in the Bronx. Annie was married, but that didn’t stop him. We’ll also look at a report that found “big gaps” in the way City Hall prepares for extreme weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Cade Metz
title: Microsoft Makes a New Push Into Smaller A.I. Systems
description: The company that has invested billions in generative A.I. pioneers like OpenAI says giant systems aren’t necessarily what everyone needs.
content: In the dizzying race to build generative A.I. systems, the tech industry’s mantra has been bigger is better, no matter the price tag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: I’m a Columbia Professor. The Protests on My Campus Are Not Justice.
description: I do not believe that the Columbia demonstrators are driven by antisemitism, but their actions have gone way too far.
content: Last Thursday, in the music humanities class I teach at Columbia University, two students were giving an in-class presentation on the composer John Cage. His most famous piece is “4'33",” which directs us to listen in silence to surrounding noise for exactly that amount of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Pennsylvania Holds Its Primaries Today. Here’s What to Watch.
description: The Democratic primary for Representative Summer Lee, a vocal Israel critic, is the contest getting the most attention on Tuesday.
content: Pennsylvanians are heading to the polls on Tuesday, with a handful of House primary races in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Terry Carter, Barrier-Breaking Actor and Documentarian, Dies at 95
description: He was a rare Black presence on “Combat!” and “The Phil Silvers Show,” then made well-regarded documentaries on luminaries like Duke Ellington and Katherine Dunham.
content: Terry Carter, who broke color barriers onstage and on television in the 1950s and ’60s and later produced multicultural documentaries on the jazz luminary Duke Ellington and the dancer-choreographer Katherine Dunham, died on Tuesday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s New Abortion Law Is a Lesson in How Meloni Governs
description: The measure, largely restating existing law, shows the prime minister’s skill at reassuring her right-wing base without sacrificing her increasingly mainstream image.
content: At a family counseling center in Verbania, a leafy lakefront town in northern Italy, employees not only explain to women the rules for getting abortions, they have also distributed leaflets supplied by a local anti-abortion group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ukraine Could Receive Some U.S. Aid ‘Within Days’
description: Also, the F.T.C. banned noncompete clauses. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a critical procedural move to tee up the final passage of the long-stalled $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. Senators are expected to pass the package as early as tonight, and President Biden said he would quickly sign it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall D. Eliason
title: Why Is the Supreme Court Making an Easy Case Related to Jan. 6 Rioters Hard?
description: Will the court go out of its way to disregard statutory language and create ambiguity where none exists?
content: Imagine that during a Supreme Court argument, protesters angry about the case storm the court building. The mob breaks doors and windows and assaults security officers while forcing its way into the chamber. Some shout that they want to hang the chief justice. The justices and attorneys are forced to flee for their lives. It’s several hours before law enforcement secures the building and the argument can resume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: U.S. universities struggle to calm campuses torn by the Gaza war.
description: Administrators at some of the most influential American universities — including New York University, Yale and Columbia — were struggling, and largely failing, on Monday to calm campuses torn by the war in Gaza.
content: Administrators at some of the most influential American universities — including New York University, Yale and Columbia — were struggling, and largely failing, on Monday to calm campuses torn by the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Mistrial Declared in Case of Arizona Rancher Accused of Murdering Migrant
description: George Alan Kelly is accused of fatally shooting Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea, an unarmed migrant from Mexico, on his 170-acre ranch in Kino Springs, Ariz., last year.
content: A judge on Monday declared a mistrial in the case of an Arizona rancher who was accused of murdering an unarmed migrant on his property after he crossed the U.S.-Mexico border last year, in a case that inflamed people on both sides of the national debate over immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Mayor Gives Panda Diplomacy a Try
description: In a city still struggling to recover from the pandemic, Mayor London Breed hopes giant pandas will lift the spirits — and the economy — of San Francisco.
content: Facing a tough re-election fight in San Francisco, Mayor London Breed has already proposed building a soccer stadium in place of an underused mall, adding a college to the hollowed-out downtown and filling the city’s quiet streets with lively night markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Hezbollah Claims Drone Attack 10 Miles Inside Israel
description: The Israeli military later said that no bases had been hit and no casualties reported.
content: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah on Tuesday claimed that it had made its deepest attack into Israel since October, striking a barracks north of the city of Acre with drones and setting off sirens across the country’s northern coastline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: 6 Smart Tips for Building a Better Grocery Budget
description: With a few simple steps, you can rein in your spending at the supermarket.
content: Shrinking products, rising prices at the market and beyond: Shoppers have been feeling the pinch at the register for some time now. And whether it’s a new feeling or a long-lasting one, creating a grocery budget can help you feel more in control over your finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Old and Young
description: How many intergenerational relationships do you have? What do you get from them?
content: Do you have any meaningful relationships with people significantly older or younger than you are? What do you get from those relationships that you might not get from those with people your own age?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Shawn Hubler
title: Why an Oregon Case Before the Supreme Court Matters So Much to California
description: A challenge to a small Oregon city’s law that imposes fines on homeless people for sleeping outdoors could have big implications for the Golden State.
content: The Supreme Court began hearing a case yesterday that could have profound implications for how the United States deals with its escalating homelessness crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: David Pecker, Ex-National Enquirer Publisher, Details How He Aided Trump
description: Testifying for the prosecution, Mr. Pecker spoke about the mutually beneficial relationship between Donald J. Trump and the supermarket tabloid.
content: David Pecker, a former publisher of The National Enquirer, on Tuesday testified about the mutually beneficial relationship between Donald J. Trump and the supermarket tabloid that started decades ago and buoyed Mr. Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Adam Moss
description: The April 23, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adam Moss. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Winkler
title: 460 Years Ago, Shakespeare Was Born Here. Or Somewhere.
description: Every year, millions flock to Stratford-upon-Avon, England, to visit the house known as Shakespeare’s Birthplace. But was he really born there? A whole industry depends on it.
content: Sometime in the late 18th century, a sign appeared outside a shambly butcher’s hut in the English town of Stratford-upon-Avon: “The Immortal Shakspeare was born in this house,” it announced, using a then common spelling of his name. Devotees began making pilgrimages — dropping to their knees, weeping, singing odes: “Untouched and sacred be thy shrine, Avonian Willy, bard Divine!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: Is Nasal Spray Addictive?
description: Some versions can lead to dependence. Here’s what we know about the risks.
content: Q: Nasal sprays help with my seasonal allergies, but I’ve heard they can be addictive. Is that true? And what should I do if I think I’m hooked?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Why David Beckham Is Suing Mark Wahlberg and F45 for Millions
description: The former soccer star entered into a promotional agreement with the gym franchise that is co-owned by the actor, but things quickly soured.
content: The former English soccer star David Beckham is entangled in a court battle against F45, a popular global fitness brand co-owned by the actor and entrepreneur Mark Wahlberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: George Santos Said He Was Running for Congress Again. (He’s Not.)
description: Less than two weeks after announcing a surprise long-shot bid for a House seat on Eastern Long Island, Mr. Santos said he was no longer pursuing the seat.
content: In the litany of lies and half-truths told by George Santos in a fanciful journey in which he was first elected to and then expelled from Congress, the one he told about his nascent campaign for a different House seat on Long Island was not exactly a lie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Woman Charged With Murder After Driving Into a Party, Killing 2 Children
description: The driver, Marshella Chidester, 66, was also charged with operating a vehicle while intoxicated. The crash injured 15 other people on Saturday.
content: A woman in Michigan was charged with second-degree murder after driving her vehicle into a building where a birthday party was taking place on Saturday, killing two children and injuring 15 other people, prosecutors announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Prosecutors Call Trump’s Echo of Fox News Host Remarks ‘Troubling’
description: Donald J. Trump amplified a false assertion by the commentator Jesse Watters that activists were infiltrating the jury in his criminal trial.
content: As prosecutors argued Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump had repeatedly broken a gag order, they called one episode “very troubling” — his sharing of a commentator’s quote disparaging prospective jurors as clandestine operators for the left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: In Silicon Valley, You Can Be Worth Billions and It’s Not Enough
description: Andreas Bechtolsheim, the first investor in Google, has an estimated $16 billion fortune. He recently settled charges that he engaged in insider trading for a profit of $415,726.
content: Andreas Bechtolsheim doesn’t like to waste time. The entrepreneur made one of the most celebrated investments in the history of Silicon Valley — the initial $100,000 that bankrolled a search engine called Google in 1998 — while on the way to work one morning. It took just a few minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Supreme Court Seems to Side With Starbucks’ Challenge to Labor Ruling
description: The case seeks to limit the National Labor Relations Board’s ability to obtain court intervention in labor cases.
content: The Supreme Court justices on Tuesday appeared willing to side with Starbucks in the company’s challenge to a federal judge’s order to reinstate workers who were attempting to unionize a store in Memphis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jon Stewart Slams How the News Media Is Covering Trump’s Trial
description: “Are you trying to make this O.J.? It’s not a chase — he’s commuting,” Stewart said on Monday’s “Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams Defends His Pick for Top Lawyer Despite City Council Opposition
description: Mayor Eric Adams praised Randy Mastro’s “impressive” career as he moves to hire him as New York City’s top lawyer. A majority of the Council is believed to oppose his nomination.
content: Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday said he intended to press forward with his expected nomination of Randy Mastro as New York City’s top lawyer despite mounting opposition from the City Council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: In Coral Fossils, Searching for the First Glow of Bioluminescence
description: A new study resets the timing for the emergence of bioluminescence back to millions of years earlier than previously thought.
content: Bioluminescence is used throughout the animal kingdom, particularly in marine environments, to lure prey, startle predators and even act as camouflage in the surrounding light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Winner, Winner, Hot Honey Chicken Dinner
description: Vallery Lomas’s new recipe for hot honey chicken is easy, delicious and already earning rave reviews.
content: Sometimes we publish a recipe on New York Times Cooking that aligns so perfectly with this newsletter and our cause — food for busy people who still want something good to eat — that I get excited to tell you about it. That’s the case with Vallery Lomas’s new roasted chicken thighs with hot honey and lime. The ingredients are minimal; the flavors are maximal. It’s easy to put together, makes clever use of staples (garlic and onion powders, honey, hot sauce), and it’s already racking up rave reviews. And really, I just want to have it for dinner as soon as possible, spritzed with lime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Ferguson
title: A Gen Z Resistance, Cut Off From Data Plans
description: Even through the Myanmar army’s communications blackout, residents of a conflict zone find moments of grace, and occasional connectivity, away from the battlefield.
content: In the night, the mountain air not quite chill enough to still the insects, young people gathered around a glow. The light attracting them was not a phone screen, that electric lure for people almost everywhere, but a bonfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Patricia Mazzei
title: Biden Campaigns on Abortion Rights in Florida, Tying State Ban to Trump
description: The Biden campaign has made abortion one of its top issues, as polling shows it is one of the few subjects in which voters place more trust in President Biden than Donald Trump.
content: President Biden on Tuesday strongly condemned a six-week abortion ban that will soon take effect in Florida, saying it would force women to endure “unbearable pain and cruelty” and blaming former President Donald J. Trump for their suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker and Claire Fahy
title: At Brooklyn Seder Protest, Jewish New Yorkers Target Schumer Over Aid
description: Approximately 200 were arrested after pro-Palestinian Jewish groups rallied near Chuck Schumer’s home, as the Senate prepared to authorize billions of dollars in aid to Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan.
content: As Senator Chuck Schumer of New York prepared for a final vote to pass an aid package that would provide $26 billion to Israel and billions more to Ukraine and Taiwan, approximately 200 protesters were arrested, according to the police, after blocking traffic in his Brooklyn neighborhood on the second night of Passover to call for an end to the United States’ military support of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: What Is a Cowboy, Anyway?
description: Cowboy style means something different for every group and era — from the vaqueros to Buffalo Bill, Madonna to the Marlboro Man, Lil Nas X to Louis Vuitton.
content: Every few years, it rides into town on a glossy white horse with the whole mixed-up mythology of frontier America crammed into its saddle bags: cowboy-core. We saw it most recently in late March, when Beyoncé turned country music on its head with the release of “Cowboy Carter.” That country-inflected album, still holding firm at No. 1 on the Billboard charts, not only lit up the BeyHive but simultaneously loosed a torrent of tropes and memes and posts and pictorials about cowboy style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: A Restaurant Critic’s Full Plate Encroaches on His Palate
description: Pete Wells’s first guide to New York’s restaurants was based on a decade of eating. To write a second, did he bite off more than he could chew?
content: At first, I thought it would be easy enough to update my list of the 100 best restaurants in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: The opening of Donald Trump’s Manhattan trial.
content: The first criminal trial of a former U.S. president began yesterday, with lawyers from each side presenting divergent visions of Donald Trump in their opening statements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: As College Students Protest, Harris Keeps Her Focus on Abortion
description: “When we think about what is at stake, it is absolutely about freedom,” Vice President Kamala Harris said during a visit to Wisconsin.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, campaigning on Monday in Wisconsin, again took sharp swipes at former President Donald J. Trump for his actions on abortion, a hot topic across the country. But she stayed silent on the war in Gaza, another issue erupting elsewhere among the critical bloc of young voters she has been courting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aodhan Beirne
title: A Guide of American Museums to Visit This Year
description: Siblings, parents and grandparents are collaborators and muses in a variety of upcoming shows around the country that highlight family traditions and bonds.
content: The value of family in the lives and work of artists is being showcased at museums across the United States this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes, Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
title: Fragments of Bird Flu Virus Discovered in Milk
description: The milk poses virtually no risk to consumers, experts said. But the finding suggests that the outbreak in dairy cows is wider than has been known.
content: Federal regulators said on Tuesday that samples of pasteurized milk from around the country had tested positive for inactive remnants of the bird flu virus that has been infecting dairy cows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess and OK McCausland
title: Kathleen Hanna’s Music Says a Lot. There’s More in the Book.
description: In “Rebel Girl,” the punk frontwoman reveals the story of her life — the men who tried to stop her, the women who kept her going and the boy who made her a mother.
content: The first draft of Kathleen Hanna’s memoir, “Rebel Girl: My Life as a Feminist Punk,” was 600 pages long. As she worked to cut the manuscript, Hanna found herself excising page after page of male violence. “It’s pretty sad, if you read the book, because there’s still a lot in there,” she told me. “I had a joke with my editor about it.” Like, she’d already removed a rape and a kidnapping and a guy who threw a wine glass at her head! “What more do you want from me?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: In a Pair of ‘Macbeth’ Productions, Only One Does Right by the Lady
description: One of Shakespeare’s most coveted roles for women gets different interpretations onstage in New York and Washington.
content: “Macbeth” isn’t one of Shakespeare’s so-called “problem plays,” and yet, the vast contradictions and reversals of the central couple often present a problem for those staging it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April, 23, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 23, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about the possibility of the U.S. imposing sanctions on Israeli military  battalions misstated a title once held by Charles Blaha. He is a former director of an office in the State Department’s bureau of democracy, human rights and labor, not a former director of the bureau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Lubell
title: As Museums’ Missions Expand, So Too Does Their Physical Space
description: Creative approaches to landscaping and a post-pandemic interest in outdoor activities are driving institutions to make better use of their grounds.
content: Once upon a time, a museum garden was a pretty straightforward proposition: an ornamental space — often a manicured lawn or stone plaza, sprinkled with flower beds and sculpture — serving as a complement to, and respite from, the elite institution next door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Orders American Journalist to Stay in Prison
description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, has been held for more than a year, awaiting trial on spying charges that he, his publisher and the United States vehemently reject.
content: A court in Moscow rejected an appeal on Tuesday by the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich against his detention, more than a year after he became the first American journalist arrested on spying charges in Russia since the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russian Deputy Defense Minister Is Detained on Bribery Charges
description: Timur Ivanov, who has long been in charge of major military construction projects and known for leading a lavish lifestyle, was held Tuesday on charges of “large scale” corruption.
content: A deputy minister of defense in Russia has been detained on charges of taking a “large scale” bribe, the country’s top law enforcement investigators announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Gaza Protests Engulfing Columbia and Other Campuses
description: Readers, including parents of suspended students, discuss the unrest. Also: Responses to Liz Cheney on the Supreme Court and Donald Trump’s immunity claim.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Slide Over, Auntie: Young Chinese Find Tasty Meals in Senior Canteens
description: The community canteens, offering huge plates for a dollar or two, have become popular among penny-pinching young professionals.
content: Inside a canteen for seniors in downtown Shanghai, a worker brandishing a sponge inched closer to Maggie Xu, 29, as she was finishing her rice and garlic-and-oil-soaked broccoli. Ms. Xu ignored her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Baltimore Says Owner of Ship That Hit Key Bridge Was Negligent
description: The owner and manager of the cargo ship that downed the Francis Scott Key Bridge asked a judge to exonerate them from liability. The city argued otherwise.
content: The City of Baltimore has said that the owner and manager of the cargo ship that brought down the Francis Scott Key Bridge last month are directly responsible for the accident and should not be allowed to avoid legal liability, according to court documents filed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Stace
title: Jane Smiley’s Folk Music Novel Hits Some Bum Notes
description: “Lucky” features a 1970s singer-songwriter who finds improbable success.
content: Fictional folk singers have generally been the butt of the joke, holy fools or total idiots: Think of “National Lampoon’s Animal House” when John Belushi’s Bluto brutally smashes the guitar of the young man whose only offense is singing “I gave my love a cherry…,” the sincere saps of “A Mighty Wind” or the Coen brothers’ prickly, unattractive Llewyn Davis. With the glorious late-career renaissance of Joni Mitchell and the eye-opening recent Joan Baez documentary “I Am a Noise,” however, perhaps the time is right for Jodie Rattler, the protagonist of Jane Smiley’s new novel, “Lucky.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex V. Cipolle
title: Reincarnating a Treasured Design Store in Minneapolis
description: The Walker Art Center looks to the past to bring back its long-admired flair for modern design and contemporary art.
content: At the Walker Art Center here, Felice Clark sits on a sofa that looks like it crawled off the set of the 1988 Tim Burton film “Beetlejuice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Howie Schwab, ESPN Researcher and Trivia Star, Dies at 63
description: He stepped out of his behind-the-scenes role in 2004 when he was cast as the ultimate sports know-it-all on the game show “Stump the Schwab.”
content: Howie Schwab, a sports nerd who parlayed his love of statistics into a long stint at ESPN that was most notable for his starring role as the ultimate trivia expert on the game show “Stump the Schwab,” died on Saturday in Aventura, Fla. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cha Cha Tang Will Serve Its Take on Hong Kong Diner Food Starting Mother’s Day
description: Onion Tree Pizza offers chicken tikka masala and saag paneer  pies, Burmese Bites opens in Midtown East and more restaurant news.
content: Opening on Mother’s Day, May 12, this pop-up rendition of a Hong Kong diner with white tablecloths will serve Cobb salad with roast pork, a Cantonese roast duck sandwich, macaroni soup with fried Spam, Cantonese French toast with taro cream and more. It’s the work of Wilson Tang, who grew up in the Manhattan Chinatown and visited Hong Kong often, and John McDonald, the owner of Hancock Street. Mr. Tang is known for restoring Nom Wah Tea Parlor in Chinatown (no longer involved, he owns other Nom Wah outlets and the brand). It runs Sundays and Mondays until early June; the chefs Doron Wong and Akiko Thurnauer will be in the kitchen. (Opens May 12)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Michael Rothfeld
title: Publisher Describes Quashing Doorman’s Claim Trump Had Child Out of Wedlock
description: The former publisher of The National Enquirer testified at Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial that he used a so-called catch-and-kill deal to silence the doorman.
content: David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer, revealed during Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on Tuesday how a team of reporters chased down a potentially explosive news tip called into the publication in 2015 that evolved into a catch-and-kill deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susannah Cahalan
title: Searching for the Real ‘Anna O.’
description: As described by Gabriel Brownstein, the basis for one of Freud’s most famous cases posed as many questions as it answered.
content: Bertha Pappenheim stopped eating and sleeping. She lost her language and ability to move. Her eyes crossed and her muscles spasmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: What Is the Rwanda Policy? U.K.’s Plan for Asylum Seekers Explained
description: The plan has been in the works for years, but the passage of a contentious bill by Britain’s Parliament puts the country closer to sending asylum seekers to the African nation.
content: After a prolonged battle in the courts and in Parliament, Britain’s Conservative government secured passage of legislation on Monday that is intended to allow the country to send asylum seekers to Rwanda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Hey, New Yorkers: Do You Live Next to an Elevated Train Line?
description: Love or hate the elevated train right outside your window? Tell us about your experience.
content: For an upcoming project, The New York Times is hoping to learn more about New Yorkers who live in apartments or homes adjacent to elevated subway tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Gag Order Hearing Is Heated as Judge Considers Citing Trump for Contempt
description: Justice Juan M. Merchan, overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, warned the former president’s lawyer that he was losing credibility.
content: The judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s trial in Manhattan held a fiery hearing on Tuesday about whether to find Mr. Trump in criminal contempt for repeatedly violating the provisions of a gag order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: A Brewery Worker’s Drunken Driving Defense: His Stomach Made the Alcohol
description: A 40-year-old man was acquitted of a drunken driving offense after doctors confirmed he had a rare condition: auto-brewery syndrome.
content: One man was charged with drunken driving after crashing his truck and spilling 11,000 salmon onto a highway in Oregon. Another was secretly recorded by his wife, who was convinced he was a closet alcoholic. And in Belgium, a brewery worker was recently pulled over and given a breathalyzer test, which said that his blood alcohol level was more than four times the legal limit for drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Says Trump Is Responsible for ‘Nightmare’ State Abortion Laws
description: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.
content: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola, Rebecca Suner, James Surdam and Lauren Leatherby
title: Our Reporter on the Fate of a Gazan University Class
description: These university graduates in Gaza finished training just one week before the war began. We reached out to everyone in the class WhatsApp group to find out what happened to them.
content: These university graduates in Gaza finished training just one week before the war began. We reached out to everyone in the class WhatsApp group to find out what happened to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes
title: Roaches’ Lullaby
description: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.
content: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Earthquakes in Taiwan Damage Buildings
description: A series of earthquakes in the city of Hualien on Monday were aftershocks from a deadly quake in early April, the authorities said.
content: A series of earthquakes in the city of Hualien on Monday were aftershocks from a deadly quake in early April, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times
